1574367198_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEG.body:
Very easy. The maniac should publicly buy an advertisement at an oldfashioned paper-newspaper and have the advertisement read: 

Timestamp by <name of the maniac>, SHA512 hash of the timestamped document file that has the size of <the file size> is: <the SHA512 hash of the file>. 

The paper newspaper timestamps the hash and has the details about, who paid for the advertisement + the name in the advertisement. The rest assumes that the hash is "secure" enough that it is not possible to easily generate reasonable documents from that hash. Oh, and yes, the maniac should flash a huge A4 paper that has both, the hash of the document and the URL, which can be ZeroNet or IPFS or any other non-censorable network URL. The web page can then have the extra details about the paper-newspaper advertisement, like the name of the newspaper or newspapers, the date, when the advertisement has been published, etc. Libraries tend to have an obligation to archive paper newspapers.

That idea is also useful to non-maniacs. For example, timestamping logs, diaries. For example, the Trump meeting notes of the former FBI director, James Comey is a fine example, where the notes should be kept private until published, yet there is a need for proof that they were not written retroactively. To prove that the notes were not written before the events that they claim to describe, they should include citations from paper-newspapers of the time, when they were written, with proper academic references to the newspaper articles that are cited.

A timestamping service may use the exact same idea by using the root hash of a Merkle tree in stead of the hash of the document. If You trust that banksters won't erase their records, then in stead of a paper-newspaper one may just create a money transfer of one cent or one dollar from one bank to another and add the newspaper advertisement text as the comment of the wire transfer. Both, the receiving bank and the sending bank log the transfer. You may want to choose the banks so that they are at jurisdiction of enemies, like one in China and another in U.S. or one in U.S. and another one in Russia.

1574821349_1HFbnmQ8wBoYBNqZy2wVfyLg19v4W.body:
You might ask Yourself, why are You complaining about that on ZeroNet in stead of complaining about that on Dat? My guess is, due to the technical reasons, the Dat "failed to get traction" even within techno-skillful hactivists like You. 

In my view the main issue with the Dat is that unlike ZeroNet, it is very tightly coupled to a difficultly buildable tool, a custom fork of a web browser. Not only are web browsers difficult to build due to huge amount of dependencies, but anything that interacts with some GUI library (QT, GTK, etc.) is difficult to build, because often times specific versions of the libraries and the related tools are needed. If the Beakerbrowser were available from a Linux distribution standard package collection, then it would be another matter from an end-user installation perspective. Until that happens, the Beakerbrowser is pretty much a windows-Mac-only application and those are not the operating systems that the most active hactivists tend to use as their main operating systems. On the other hand, thanks to the 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/faq

the ZeroNet can run on both, Linux and Windows10. Another fundamental issue with all P2P-applications, including a modern (but horribly buggy) file sharing system like the 
https://www.tribler.org/
is that they access the storage, where the downloaded files have been saved. Network traffic can be throttled, so network consumption of the P2P-systems is not that big of a problem, but disk access slows the workstation down quite a lot, not to mention that ZeroNet/FreeNET/Dat data takes a considerable amount of disk space.

The issue with the hashbase.io is that it is a central point of failure in the sense that supermafia/government may start to demand censorship from the party that runs the hashbase.io. If people are used to using the URLs that have the form of dat://<foo>.hashbase.io, then shutting down the hashbase.io or changing its data makes it possible to interrupt the use of the Dat.

1574806526_14dsVvztuXjBxWmk4s4HjUnxuN4Ae.body:
Humans differ from the rest of the animals mainly by SPENDING A LOT OF TIME ON PLAYING. Playing is a form of simulation, a form of mentally trying out different scenarios by trying to answer a lot of "what if..." questions. Games, including video games, become a problem, when they no longer give any learning experience, like when a gamer knows the game level already so well that it easily beats all the AI monsters in all possible variations. If there are other human players in the game, then they vary the game and change the same game level to a new learning experience. 

All in all, it reduces to what develops the given player, human the most. If You play tetris or pong all day long, then You have to be mentally retarded or have dementia, but for the mentally retarded and demented people even that is a Good Thing. There are actually daycare facilities for the very old people, who have partly lost their memory and simplistic games like puzzles, basically small children games, help those people. For them tetris or pong might also be helpful. So, to say, "games are Good/Bad" would be too simplistic. Even chess can be dumb, if played without trying new things out.

Actually, if we look at how many stars there exists and that the planets, according to our current knowledge, IN THIS UNIVERSE, consists of the same chemical elements that are known at the periodic table of chemical elements
https://www.ptable.com/
then plain mathematically there is a good chance that at some other galaxy there exists AT LEAST one other planet like Earth, with life forms that are based on some similar molecules. So, Earth is not that unique. Add to that the fact that in universe timeline even our solar system is not that old, stars form and they burn out, our own bodies might contain atoms that came to our solar system with some flying asteroid from some other blown-up solar system. After all, we're using the plants of the planet Earth Dinosaur era for traveling with airplanes and diesel trains and ships. 

An interesting question might be, if a hydrogen atom consists of just one proton and one electron and all the rest of the basic chemical elements are synthesized with nuclear reactions, like a hydrogen bomb, in stars, then what might the series of events be to get from sparsely distributed hydrogen atoms to a solar system with that many different elements. The nucleus of a hydrogen atom can be seen as a very high frequency photon, a "piece of light". If You calculate the frequency/wavelength of such light by taking the hydrogen atom nucleus diameter as the wavelength and then using the 

photon_energy = Planck_constant * frequency

and then the Einstein's

E=m*c^2

where E is Energy, m is mass, c is the speed of light, getting

m*c^2 = multiply(Planck_constant, frequency)

then You get a very close figure, what happens to be considered the mass of the hydrogen atom as measured by chemists. That is to say

m_of_hydrongen_nucleus_as_a_photon = multiply(Planck_constant, frequency) / c*c

differs from the m_of_hydrogen_nucleus_as_measured_by_chemists only by a factor of 5 or less. That is remarkably close, given that the Planck constant contains figures like 10^(some number bigger than 10).

So, are humans unique, worth to be saved? Well, once upon a time people thought that the Earth is the center and the Sun revolves around the Earth, not the other way around. 1575161695_1KDpaUh79hAu9u5dFdZeJptTi2u3w.body:
Actually, ZeroNet is NOT the First. Historically FreeNET might qualify as the first by some criteria and back in the day, when people used phone lines for data connections and the phone companies lacked proper logging, the Usenet was de facto anonymous, because the logging of phone calls was that poor. It's kind of hard to imagine nowadays, but the Usenet, the same "internet" that the Linux kernel was supposedly first announced at, actually was truly anonymous, if people wanted to stay anonymous. The technical details:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4tHyZdtXULw

In addition to the Usenet 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet

there's another archaic pone-internet called FidoNet

https://www.fidonet.org/

and somewhere at the history is also the 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopher_(protocol)

As time went on, the various logging capabilities of various parties, including the NSA and the phone companies, improved and there was the need for something like the 

https://www.torproject.org/

Too long history to write it all down here, but long story short, there is quite a huge amount of academic papers about anonymous communication, also many P2P-projects, but the academics only create proofs of concepts that only demonstrate nice math and do not take to account the many real-life requirements. The academics say that they get grant money only for "science" and not "engineering", as if those 2 could be separated in a proper development project. The academics totally ignore the fact that it is the creation of practical things that furnishes the most interesting and may be also the most challenging questions for the theoretical study. The rest of the freedom-of-speech software projects tend to fail mainly because the people, who start them, lack the rigor to complete and polish the project properly. Often times the founders of the project are some hactivists, social warriors, artists, web-developers, not people with deep-technical background and patience. Without the Tor tunneling the ZeroNet is actually NOT anonymous, but the the ZeroNet is successful, because it is properly engineered, worked on patiently. The ZeroNet developers aim to develop usable software in stead of just slamming some emotional dirty hack together or writing academic papers for the sake of getting famous and thus more grant money. For example, the 

https://www.tribler.org/about.html

project team claims to have received over 3 million € for the development of the P2P file sharing software, the Tribler, and yet the project still has so horrible quality problems that people get better functionality by installing the old "aMule" from openSUSE Linux Packman package repository. Besides ZeroNet, Tor/TorBrowser and aMule there is one other project that seems to be capable of delivering:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pi-kreA52oI
https://beakerbrowser.com/
https://github.com/beakerbrowser/

So, ZeroNet is far from being the only one, but it is certainly among the most technically sound projects. A stellar example of a set of projects that are run by hactivists that just can't get their code properly done is the set of most popular projects at 

https://fediverse.party/

From functionality point of view the Fediverse projects look pretty neat, except anonymity, but most of the people, who wrote the implementations, clearly did not invest much time on thinking about the dependencies of their projects or what it takes to port the projects not just between different operating systems, but from one Linux distribution to another. Let alone the installation of those projects. Also, as the Microsoft case demonstrates, spending a lot of money will not help with software quality. For me it is even hard to comprehend, what could all be done by proper open source developers for even just a fraction of the money that the Microsoft spends on its development teams and managers, specially the useless managers and I'm not even talking about Bill Gates level managers here. It's the reliability and quality of implementation that allowes the Tor to flourish and what allows the ZeroNet to outperform much better financed projects like the Tribler.

1575869098_1MXVsMNFA5sP6AbbVirbrjzWsMeWy.body:
Welcome, but expect new tools to take some time to learn. Including the ZeroNet.

You may think of the ZeroNet as a collection of ordinary Microsoft Word or LibreOffice document files that are shared on LAN and edited collectively, except that in stead of a Microsoft Word or LibreOffice specific composite file format the document file is a folder with HTML and some ZeroNet specific text files. Those "document files", actually folders, reside at

    <ZeroNet isntallation folder>/data

A ZeroNet forum, like this one, is just one collectively editable document, where the individual blog posts are distributed over the P2P-network as separate data chunks and aligned in a row locally. For example, if You post to a ZeroNet forum while flying above clouds with no internet connection, then Your forum posts are sent to the network after landing, when Your laptop has internet connection again. The rights management is handled by public key cryptography and the private keys of a ZeroNet node owner are held at 

    <ZeroNet isntallation folder>/data/users.json

That's the file You need to back up to avoid loosing Your identity on ZeroNet. Although the ZeroNet does not provide anonymity without being tunneled through Tor (as of 2019_12 it is NOT tunneled through Tor by default), it is highly recommended to use multiple identities to confuse search engines. One way to generate multiple identities is to stop the ZeroNet node, move the users.json away from the data folder and restart the ZeroNet node. To swap an identity, stop the ZeroNet node, swap the users.json, start the ZeroNet node.

The ZeroNet has been developed by ThePirateBay as a response to the takedown of their server cluster. A very similar solution, but with different motivations, has been created by the developers of the 
https://beakerbrowser.com/
The core of the Beakerbrowser is the 
https://github.com/datproject/docs/blob/master/papers/dat-paper.pdf
In my opinion the ZeroNet as a technology is architecturally more sound than the Beakerbrowser, because it can be used with any mainstream web browser without having to meet the operating system and CPU specific dependencies of a custom web browser. What makes the compilation of a web browser extremely hard is that in addition to the operating system specific API changes, specially at the 3D acceleration side (think of WebGL), the list of dependencies includes the various release version specific versions of build tools that are needed for compiling both, the web browser and its dependencies. However, the Beakerbrowser does have fancier desktop integration at the expense of future availability and portability. For example, the ZeroNet node can be run on a Linux machine that does not have any GUI/X11 installed by tunneling the 127.0.0.1:43110 over an SSH connection, but as of 2019_12 I'm not sure, if something like that can be easily done with the Dat/Beakerbrowser tools.

1575800810_1DfbNohg1UZxEJXMGS4W46bSSh3Ag.body:
I'm not sure, if a PC/x86/AMD64 can be made like that, but if You just want to give a hell of a lot of computing power to A SINGLE OPERATING SYSTEM PROCESS, then that can be done by using some extra compute cards/accelerator cards or by manufacturing Your own accelerator card and if You have the skills, then You might even get a way with as little as 5k€ budget. For example, You might want to create a custom board with multiple 
https://www.parallella.org/
chips. Or, You might also just buy a few hundred RISC-V SoC's
https://www.sifive.com/
or OpenRISC SoC's
https://openrisc.io/

I think that You need to keep in mind is that the speed of light, the speed of electrical signals, is finite, which means that it takes time for data to move from one CPU to another, from RAM to CPU, REGARDLESS OF HOW FAST THE CPU IS. Another thing to consider is the Amdahl's law, which basically says that if a program consists of sequential parts like

    my_program(){
        function_foo_1() // takes t1 time units to execute on a single core
        function_foo_2() // takes t2 time units to execute on a single core
        function_foo_3() // takes t3 time units to execute on a single core
    } // the end of my_program

and the function_foo_2() can NOT be parallelized while the function_foo_1() and the function_foo_3() can be infinitely parallelized, id est run in parallel on infinitely many CPU-cores, then even with infinitely many CPU-cores available, the time that it takes to execute the my_program() is still

    (t1/infinitely_huge_number) + t2 + (t3/infinitely_huge_number) = 0 + t2 + 0 = t2

because if the function_foo_2() can not be parallelized, id est it executes just on a single core, the rest of the cores, the infinite number of them, are useless during the execution of the function_foo_2(). Whether some function_foo_X can be parallelized, even the extent that it can be parallelized, depends on the algorithms. For example, write operations into a central "database" (think of Your bank account, there's just one live record of it in the bank) are fundamentally sequential. There is data parallelism, id est images can be processed in parallel, bank transfers of different persons can be done in parallel (to a certain extent, with some limitations), but often times there are still some sequential operations. For example, file writes and reads through one read-write head of a magnetic HDD are fundamentally sequential, despite the efforts of the operating system to try to cache the files in RAM to make the read-write operations appear as if they were parallel.

If You are doing crypto-mining, then You may want to look at the different FPGA options.
https://www.terasic.com.tw/cgi-bin/page/archive.pl?Language=English&CategoryNo=13&List=Simple
You may want to start with the FPGAs that are supported by the 
http://www.clifford.at/icestorm/

If You are more into software, then You may want to learn a new programming language, an autoparallelizing C++ replacement, ParaSail:

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/parasail-programming-language
http://www.parasail-lang.org/

If You are not necessarily into the raw performance, just want to experiment with interesting parallel architectures, then a thing to consider might be a microcontroller that has Forth cores:
http://www.greenarraychips.com/
In the end it's still the speed of light and the time it takes for the transistors to switch that matters. The architecture, be it a classical RAM-machine (read: all classical CPUs with registers that do not have to be on the chip itself from theory of computation point of view, just the ability to address bytes at RAM is enough from theoretical point of view) or some "stack machine" or some FPGA is just an optimization hack, as are CPU caches, branch prediction, SIMD-instructions, vector-architecture, etc. Architecture, the speed optimization hacks, are important in practice, but irrelevant from theory of computation point of view. Actually, just for fun, You do not even need any extra hardware. For intellectual experimentation You may just write a simulator, may be in C++ using OpenMP. One silly, but impressive, idea that has been implemented was to write a program for a tiny, slow-as-hell, MCU and that program simulates the operation of a more advanced CPU that has (simulated) memory management unit and then the Linux operating system has been (cross-)compiled for and booted on that simulated CPU:
http://dmitry.gr/index.php?r=05.Projects&proj=07.+Linux+on+8bit

1576021462_1K8NrwqEfy49zAMWzHgywnToZib7P.body:
The short answer is: NO.

First, define internet? There are the P2P-networks like the ZeroNet, I2P, etc. and then there is the censored clear-net. Basically there are 3 things at play: the web page as a data set, the computer that has the data set and the data transmission connection between the comuter with the dataset and the computer that the human uses as a workstation/terminal. The idea behind the ZeroNet and FreeNET is that the document, the "site"/zite is just passed around from computer to computer and if some connections between computers break, then some other computer that can be still connected to might have the document and serve it. The idea behind the classical censored-net and the Tor services is that the data, the "site"/"zite" stays at the "server" and in order to see the web_page/"site"/"zite", the workstation has to be able to connect to the computer that has the data_set/"site"/"zite"/web_page.

A more detailed description of the ZeroNet architecture is at my comment at
http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1575869098_1MXVsMNFA5sP6AbbVirbrjzWsMeWyhTwk8/This+has+a+steep+learning+curve

What You want in the case of a classical internet blackout, at the situation, where the Government has turned off connections to clear-net outside of its controlled territory is a "mesh network": an a separate data transmission channel that forms from cellphones that send data to each other without using the phone company cellphone towers. The network that forms from cellphones can then be combined with satellite phones and that gives a totally independent network. There are privacy issues and "operational security" issues with that, id est the people setting it up will probably be killed or tortured or at least imprisoned by the repressive Government, but that is the technical solution and if the mesh network builders have proper technical background, then they can take some precautions to not get caught. Setting up a proper mesh network is NOT something that some journalists or non-technical activists can do without getting caught. But, it is doable. Some mesh network related references:


https://www.open-mesh.org/projects/open-mesh/wiki
http://servalproject.org/
https://piratebox.cc/faq
https://project-byzantium.org/
https://freedombone.net/
https://guifi.net/en/node/38392

https://commotionwireless.net/
https://github.com/opentechinstitute/commotion-meshbook

https://github.com/ProjectSPAN
http://netsukuku.freaknet.org/

Alternatively You may resort to pre-IPvX-internet era technologies that use plain phone lines and oldschool modems, with the hope that the repressive Government only switches off the classical internet and not voice phone system. The oldschool technologies are:

FidoNet:
https://www.fidonet.org/
http://ftsc.org/

Usenet:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet

1576265919_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
All radio connections have the problem that unless directed antennae are used at the receiver and there is a direct line of sight (fog is OK) from the receiver to the transmitter, the receivers are all vulnerable too radio jamming. Jamming also works, when the jammer transmitter resides right at the line of sight of the receiver directed antenna.

What regards to transmitters, the way I understand, the U.S. army killed people in Iraq and Afghanistan according to their cell phone movement patterns and the independence warrior Dudayev got killed by the Russian army by locating his satellite phone.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dzhokhar_Dudayev

You may want to use laser links instead and keep the transmissions at short distances, like from house to house, ~40m maximum, for both, reliability and security. For longer distances You may try to use the power line modems.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power-line_communication

I do not know about the Lokinet, but the ZeroNet's security is just fine, if used with Tor. There is a risk that a zite includes an image with a clear-net URL, which then reveals the IP-address of the viewer, but if the viewer directs all traffic through Tor, then that shouldn't be a problem either. 

The fundamental issue with ZeroNet security is that if its traffic is tunneled through any anonymization network, then the P2P based efficiency of ZeroNet diminishes. The original legal scheme for the ZeroNet was that if a lot of people serve pirated content, then the Police runs out of resources at jailing everybody. ZeroNet was NOT designed for use by small, niche, groups. Nor is ZeroNet a secure communication application. It was never meant to be one. Besides, even, if ZeroNet were properly secure, the linguistic analysis would reveal the original author anyway. That's also the reason, why it is not possible to use one's own malware for "shady activities" and why the NoSuchAgency and such mix-and-match opposing team's code to their malware and publish their own malware so that the other team could use it, allowing the original authors of the malware also to start using their own malware.

May be the way to think is, what kind of other features, in addition to the cookies, browser developers can add to the mainstream browser to make browsing the network even less private and make everyone pay Google, Facebook, Microsoft even when not directly using any of their servers.

Obviously the cookie-nag-screens are an absurd, bad, joke from Brussels, but I haven't noticed any actual web browser developers doing anything about it. For example, if all people turned off all of the cookie support, then nobody could use cookies and if cookies do not work, the nag screens would not be necessary, because the sites would be done without using any cookies.

If You guys in the U.S. do not like the cookie-nag-screens, then switch off cookies in Chrome and Mozilla. For some reason the "so privacy aware" Mozilla Corporation does not want to do that while being perfectly aware, what businesses do with their cookie support. I do point out that modern browsers also have a built-in database that has "site origin" limits, meaning, a page from one domain at one tab can communicate with a JavaScript at another tab, as long as the page at the other tab originates from the same domain. The database is persistent, id est if the browser is closed, the data will be available at the next startup of the browser, provided that the browser cache did not get emptied. That is to say, user experience wise there is NO NEED FOR COOKIES. Cookies are used at modern web sites only for tracking. All the rest, the functionality that the end users care about, can be done with other means, without cookies.

1576347710_1T4nUY5eDwwMk3zFjh27ZQCqkVpPx.body:
Well, I guess VPN to some western country is Your best bet, provided that You can avoid the man-in-the-middle attack at the Iranian border. For a start You may want to start Your ZeroNet node with the command line option:

     --force_encryption

There's also the problem that if You encrypt everything without using steganography, then the censors at the border can know, who needs to be raided for evidence collection. If You have a lot of money, then You may want to buy yourself a satellite phone that also allows some slow data connection to come through. Forget about using YouTube or downloading huge files, but You might be able to use ZeroNet and some old-fashioned bulletin boards like Usenet and FidoNet. Here are some FidoNet related links:

https://www.fidonet.org/
http://ftsc.org/
http://filegate.net/

One measure that You may also want to consider is to use some less-mainstream operating system, because government spying malware products are developed for operating systems that are widely used and it does not make financial sense for the malware("law enforcement software") creation company to support very esoteric operating systems. STOP USING WINDOWS. As Linux is nowadays also pretty mainstream, Linux is not such a good bet either. You may want to try Debian based GNU Hurd:

https://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/hurd/running/distrib.html

Or, may be You might try out something as extreme as the
https://kolibrios.org/en/

You probably have to use multiple computers: one for working with mainstream software and the other one with the esoteric operating system for the political and "illegal" things like gay porn and political talk. Also, You probably want to keep Your files encrypted. The GNU Hurd has a very nice concept of "Translators", which are like the Linux userspace file system drivers (FUSE), except that the GNU Hurd translators are cleaner, probably an inspiration for the Linux FUSE. You can write Your own encryption software that automatically encrypts/decrypts yor files like the 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECryptfs

I suggest that You do NOT use the ecryptfs, because it uses a flawed kernel module that literally crashes the Linux kernel and corrupts files, causing data loss. It also uses too short keys. What You may want to do is to use at least 200kB long key like it is used with one-time-pad, except that You re-use the key, making the encryption weaker as a compromise and to mitigate the weakening, use salting, id est add random numbers to the byte-stream to hide the key a bit. A salting idea:

A block of N bytes, 4<N, starts with a randomly generated byte. The rest of the N-1 bytes consist of N-2 cleartext bytes and at least one other randomly generated byte.  At first the N byte sequence looks like:


    (1. randomly generated byte)(N-2 cleartext bytes at the order as they appear at the cleartext)(2. randomly generated byte)

For the sake of conciseness I designate them as

    B_rand_1, B_clear_1,B_clear_2,...,B_clear_(N-2), B_rand_2

The B_rand_1 range is 0..255, because it is just 1 byte, 8 bits. The next task is to construct 2 functions:

    set_of_indices_shuffle = func_1(B_rand_1)
    set_of_indices_DEshuffled = func_2(B_rand_1)

It's a matter of creativity, how to create the func_1 and func_2, but the idea is that the func_1 is used for swapping the order of the N-1 bytes, shuffling them, and the func_2 is used for restoring the order of the N-1 bytes, at least one of them being the randomly generated one, the B_rand_2. Swapping the order of bytes is not necessarily a fast operation, but this algorithm is not just about speed, but also about security. The shuffled form should then be XOR'ed with the key, encrypted. That is to say, at encryption the XOR-ing comes AFTER the shuffling and at decryption the XOR-ing comes BEFORE the DEshuffling. Basically, a primary school child can write this program in C programming language or at least one of my early childhood friends, over 20 years ago, did it, but it's awesome, because it is truly secure despite being simple. With long enough key it is even more secure than the modern encryption algorithms.

The actual problem that ZeroNet will have and may be does not yet have that much is the lack of personalized search engines that actually work on the person's own computer and truly serve the person. Those will probably not be popular too soon, because those would need their own machine due to high CPU-load and high IO-traffic, unless someone sells those as separate appliances that can be attached to LAN or creates a special Linux distribution that installs some per-configured version of the personalized search engine. I believe that old laptops will make great personal search engine appliances. The main issue will be that almost all laptops are with an Intel or AMD CPU, which can self start to impose censorship through the "trusted/secure zone" mechanism, where the Intel CPU is actually running MINIX3 operating system at the "secure zone".

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Aex9RwgHHQ

https://www.cs.vu.nl/~ast/intel/

May be it will change, if the new laptops will use the new RISC-V or OpenRISC SOC's or FPGAs in stead of Intel and AMD CPUs, but the Raspberry Pi computers might be usable in a laptop only, if the laptop is actually a Raspberry Pi cluster, where the different IO channels(network, each USB for connecting USB-disks) is delegated to some dedicated Raspberry Pi with some FPGA-shield. 

So, I suggest that the "artist types" will not get their hopes up with the ZeroNet and alike, because at the technical side of things the ZeroNet and other P2P-systems have a long way to go and part of the issue is hardware, not even  software. The thing with all P2P storage systems, of which the ZeroNet is just one flavour of, is that they fundamentally need a lot of IO, as everything is served by the nodes. It's the hardware that does that IO.

It seems to me that according to Your contemplation the personal, INDIVIDUAL, interest is in conflict with the interest of having a good living environment, but in my opinion there is no such conflict. What regards to the community part, well, all passengers of the Titanic probably wished that there were enough life boats for everybody, because that way it is certain that even  if a person is some soulless 1. class 1%-nter-bastard, he/she can have his/her servants with him. So, again, there is no fundamental conflict of interests between the 1. class passengers and the lower class passengers in that particular matter. The conflicts arose, when there weren't enough lifeboats, but everybody probably agrees with the statement that it would be a Good Thing to have enough lifeboats so that everybody can escape the sinking ship without drowning. That is to say, TOTALLY PERSONAL INDIVIDUAL INTERESTS CAN BE TOTALLY IN LINE WITH THE INTERESTS OF THE COMMUNITY AS A WHOLE. It's, when one party starts to live at the expense of the other or tries to grab the resources that others  need for survival, when the conflicts start.

On the micro level, the only way to really know the other person is to be with him/her in a situation, where that other person believes to desperately need a resource that is so limited that either You get the resource or the other person gets the resource and the resource can not be shared. The possibility to share a resource alleviates the situation to the point that the situation is not that desperate. For Example, even a single shot of vaccine might be halved, oxygen masks might be used by sharing it, etc. In practice, it does not even come to the sharing part, because bastards fail that test much earlier. 

What regards to the open source part, well, the problem with closed source, including freeware, is that in addition to the security related problems, possible malware, etc, the closed source software is available only as long as its creators make it available for the modern hardware and operating system combinations. Hardware changes. Operating system APIs change. There is the option of using emulators,  like the Commodore64 era vintage personal computer software is run, but that only works, if the computer that runs the emulator is much more powerful than the emulated computer or has some special purpose hardware. The moment special purpose hardware comes to play, it's a niche project and even if the special purpose hardware is not that expensive, like the ~200€ FPGA-borards in 2020, creating software/firmware/Hardware-Description-Language-code for it is a lot of work, not to mention the fact that development tools also have dependencies in terms of applications software, operating system, hardware (operating system depends on hardware). What the Micro$oft did really well back in the day was that they figured it out, how to sell huge amounts of licenses IN BULK: they sold licenses to megacorporations, who's IT-departments love the fact that all computers are "alike". Nobody else did that before and the Apple was not able to furnish as much hardware as the different IBM clones were able to furnish, not to mention the probable price difference, where Apple is the expensive one and the Micro$oft+IBM-clones are the cheaper option. In electronics industry there is the term SECOND SOURCE, which stands for a manufacturer that is not the manufacturer that initially brought the part to the market, but that produces the part with the same quality. That's why the Intel pretended to tolerate the AMD at its early days. The Pentagon had a requirement that military equipment uses only those components that have at least one second source manufacturer. The same with software: a closed source program LACKS THE SECOND SOURCE MANUFACTURER. Think of the StarOffice/OpenOffice/LibreOffice case: only thanks to the 2. source manufacturer analogue has that project survived. Even software developers physically DIE and only the open source software projects can live longer than their original publisher, be the original publisher a corporation or an individual. 

A stellar example is the scientific computing code in Fortran. A true software dinosaur, but still being used, because it is well tested and carefully created by professional mathematicians. If a person graduates a University at ~age 24, matures its specialist skills for about 10 years, may be writes something really good, good from technical point of view, not business point of view (business success can be achieved with technical CRAP), at about age 35 or 40, and then the project matures also about 10 years, then the original author of the software is about 50 years old by the time his really good stuff hits "niche mainstream", which is not the same as business success, but a popularity among other experienced specialists. Give the project then another 40 years of use, which is the case with many software utilities like grep, tar, etc. and it is very likely the case that the software is widely used, but its original authors have literally died off, passed away. I haven't heard that the authors of the grep and the tar are billionaires and at the front cover of the Time magazine, but from a specialist point of view, not business point of view, those authors are a total success-story and certainly heroes of the HUMAN RACE. Even the Leonardo da Vinci wasn't a billionaire analogue back in his day. He was just a freelancing engineer, who had to move from one town to another to avoid being killed by religious nuts, a lot like the Albert Einstein had to flee the Nazis.

Indeed, if You take a photo of a busy city street, then that photo will also be probabilistically totally unique, because there just was not no other camera with those camera parameters at that angle at that location looking at that busy city street with exactly those humans and cars being exactly at that particular position at that particular lightning. Totally unique. And yet, the image has structure THAT IS NOT UNIQUE and not all of that uniqueness is being used for learning. A lot like tree branches swinging in the wind, with the leaves of the tree as a group of leaves probabilistically being at a totally unique position that even a single insect on any one of the leaves changes. And yet, the idea, the structure of the swinging tree branch is not unique. But even if it were, software is software, data is data and data can be copied, data as a representation of software can be copied and executed on another compatible computer. 

One interesting thing about computers and software is that it is possible to be totally mathematically correct and exact and at the same tame tell nothing about the system as a whole, a lot like all possible information about a brick of a house does not say all about the houses that can be built from such bricks. I may say that mathematically it is correct to say that the moment there is a way to crate a Boolean logic operation pair (negation, conjunction) or the pair (negation, disjunction), it is possible to use the 

https://planetmath.org/DeMorgansLaws

for creating all the rest of the Boolean logic functions and with the use of the feedback loops the flip-flops and registers and summation circuits, integer multiplication circuits, etc.

http://www.csun.edu/~rd436460/DigitalElectronics/Chapter%205.pdf 

and from there onwards it is possible to create RAM-machines (modern classical CPUs are all RAM-machines) or stack-machines, like those of the Java VM or Forth programming language based microcontrollers at

http://www.greenarraychips.com/

or whatever other appliance that we nowadays call "a computer". But that does not say anything about the actual architecture details of the machine. It might e a singe core Intel 386 CPU or some multi-core ARM CPU or some GPU or some FPGA/CPLD or some neural network simulating SoC or just some "small" 8bit microcontroller (quotes, because there are over thousand logic gates even within the smallest of the microcontrollers). That is to say, just claiming that "it is just an input-output thing and nothing more" is formally correct, but TOTALLY INCONCLUSIVE. Formally, of course, You can say that a computer is just one state machine that has input-output and nothing more and You are correct, but at the same time You totally ignore the aspects that are related to the state of that state machine. There's A LOT in that state, just like a computer with installed software does not differ from itself from the era, when software was not installed to it, by anything other than just some bits at its hard disk. It's just input-output and some state description bits on hard-disk, and yet, there IS a HUGE DIFFERENCE. People spend their whole careers MAKING ONLY THAT DIFFERENCE, creating that state description, CREATING SOFTWARE.

Basically, You might ask Yourself, WHAT IS INFORMATION in Your human model context? The mathematically correct answer that information is a series of bits, DOES NOT QUALIFY, because if it did, then You would have to admit that human brains run software that can be described by а series of bits and all the rest of it.

I guess the question is not specific to satellite phones, but rather, what will happen, if the twisted pair cable is pulled from the machine while it is downloading something. May be one way to test it is to buy an ordinary cheap WiFi router, connect its WAN to the so to speak home nework, "home LAN", and the LAN side of the router to the computer that runs the ZeroNet. In my view the main beauty of the ZeroNet is that it TECHNICALLY DELIVERS and is ARCHITECTURALLY WELL THOUGHT OUT, unlike FreeNET and many other P2P-lets-make-the-Internet-free-again-Hurray projects. The closest project to the ZeroNet project that I know of is the Dat protocol based 
https://beakerbrowser.com/
but it has the problem that it is so closely tied to the browser that the long term availability of the deployment deliverables of the Beaker Browser project is questionable. 

The main problem with the FreeNET is that it can be compiled with a very specific Java version and some of its dependencies are de facto closed source, because the source has not been stored at the FreeNET's own repository and the original authors of the dependencies have not kept their open source project online. The FreeNET has a honorable place in the history of the free-er-linked-document-collections, but it is a dinosaur.

The downside of the ZeroNet is that its newest GitHub versions that are written in Python3, do not run on the distros that I have tested them to run on, so I have to run one older ZeroNet version that uses Python2. If the ZeroNet developers do not get that issue fixed and just think about new features without thinking about robust availability, then the ZeroNet will go down the same tubes that the other lets-make-the-Internet-Free-again projects have gone. 

Interestingly the lets-make-the-Internet-Free-again type of projects tend to be with a really shoddy architecture, their authors seem to be some sort of applied artists, web developers, not software developers, because their code dependencies have not been carefully chosen at all, their code tends to be just smashed together from whatever-happens-to-be-fashionable-today, without any kind of thought put into the long-term availability of those dependencies or what the dependencies themselves depend on. Sometimes I have an impression that some artist type Social Justice Warriors develop those systems, not professional software developers. The ZeroNet seems to be a nice exception to that nasty "rule".

> [6283822](#comment_13_12sCaEUFqE6g3JrDqmEA8pn9yrgxwkZQMe): I think it's zeronet scaling issue may be

One scaling issue that the ZeroNet certainly has is that all of the downloaded zites are at a single folder, the data folder. File systems become slow, if a folder has about 10k files or folders. The solution to that problem is what the doxygen has been doing already over 10 years: distribute files in a tree of folders so that no vertex has more than about 2000 children. In the case of the ZeroNet, the zites have a nice semirandom address, so in stead of placing the zite folders directly to the data folder, the data folder might have a subfolder called "zites" and that might then have subfolders that match with the first letter of the zite address/folder name. The idea would be:

    data/zites/a/F/aFOOdowjfoipfioeripoufgeripfgdipridfh
    data/zites/a/B/aBARdowjfoipfioeripoufgeripfgdipridfh
    ...
    data/zites/A/w/Awwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww
    data/zites/A/x/Axwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww
    ...
    data/zites/b/F/bFOOdowjfoipfioeripoufgeripfgdipridfh
    data/zites/b/B/bBARdowjfoipfioeripoufgeripfgdipridfh
    ...
    data/zites/6/F/6FOOwhateverelsetherestoftheaddress
    ...
    data/zites/z/F/zFOOwu33349yu890777777777777777
    data/zites/z/B/zBARwjow98292984y24248723642348

Adding just 2 layers like that will already alleviate the situation a lot, because with case sensitive characters, each having at least 26*2=52 values per character, with digits 52+10=62 values per character, a 2 layer solution minimizes the number of zite folders per folder by at least 62*62=3844 fold. Not good enough for proper servers and data centers with distributed file systems like the

http://www.xtreemfs.org/
https://www.beegfs.io/
https://www.gluster.org/
https://lizardfs.org/
https://moosefs.com/
https://tahoe-lafs.org/
https://ceph.io/

but good enough for a start. 4 layers does not hurt either, once You're already at it.

Assuming that they will not delete their own posts from the forums that they themselves control, the solution might be a classical RSS reader. There's a distinction between being able to publish something after one has lost control of one's own servers/keys and being able to publish something while having control of one's own equipment/accounts/keys. There's also the problem that any truly anonymous forum, even if its initiator/hosting_party can not censor it, can be just  flooded with robots. The Bitmessage tries to limit that with "proof of work" based signing, but clearly a government is able to just put a whole datacenter behind the effort and still flood it with crap, effectively censoring it, which means that ultimately people have to be able to automatically filter all posts. Poster ID based filtering is effective, but it eliminates newcomers, who just lack the reputation points to pass the filter, not to mention the use of temporary IDs without explicitly tying the IDs together. 

Probably the best option is that people run their own blog software Zites and the reading of those Zites is done by having an ordinary RSS-reader scan them, just that the RSS address is then the ZeroNet specific 127.0.0.1:43110:/foo and Your role is just to list the blogs at Your Zite, so that people can initialize their RSS-readers.

> [anon05](#comment_38_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): Problem with RSS is they need to be running a server 24/7 or people won't be able to see their content.

I'm not sure that I fully understand, what You mean by this. In the case of ZeroNet forums, the ZeroNet forums are readable from a local machine even, when there is no internet connection. To get data from one computer to another there is a need for some kind of a data transfer anyway, be it phsyically IPv4 network or some USB-stick or DVD or even paper carrier. An RSS-reader that indexes ZeroNet forums actually indexes the URLs that point to the local machine, the 127.0.0.1:Foo . It's basically that in a way You are right: if a person wants to use a computer to read email, forums, chat-room content, then the person needs to switch the computer on and after reading it is OK to switch the computer off again, provided that the computer updated the data during the time, when a human was reading the email.

The RSS+ZeroNet approach is a modular approach. The ZeroNet handles the redundancy and data replication and the RSS reader handles the indexing, spam-filtering, analysis, search, the creation of  the discussion thread.

> [anon05](#comment_39_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): what's the advantage over using ZeroNet over the regular web interface?

The very advantages, why the ZeroNet was created at first place: decentralization, data replication, data redundancy. ZeroNet is not just some forum software or yet-another-web-software. The anti-censorship measures can be seen a lot like in military terms "security" can be seen in terms of multiple, individual tasks that jointly provide the proper security. For example, part of the anti-censorship measure is data redundancy: blow up a datacenter or "confiscate" the servers, but data is in many places, too many places to "confiscate" or to blow up. Switch off the Internet, but if the zites have been previously downloaded like podcasting MP3-files, then people can read the forums/blogs even, when there is no internet connection. Securing something against attackers should be seen as a modular task that has sub-tasks. The ZeroNet has its role and the Tor has its role and the 2 together make a nice whole. You seem to have a task at hand that has sub-tasks that the ZeroNet+Tor handles very well.

> [anon05](#comment_40_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): Yeah, but how does using RSS with it improve any of that?

It does NOT and it is NOT even meant to improve any of that. It adds NEW FUNCTIONALITY by creating a forum thread from posts that only their authors can delete. I understand that You wanted a forum thread, where nobody can remove posts except the authors of the posts. That's what the RSS-reader creates, with the additional functionality of allowing the RSS-reader user to apply its own spam filters. A blog post would be in the role of a forum posting.

> [anon05](#comment_41_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): Then the main disadvantage is if the owner of the site deletes the post before me (or someone else) is able to connect.

Obviously You have to get the data to Your computer before it is deleted from all nodes of the network! What do You expect?!

> [anon05](#comment_41_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): I wonder how mature and usable IPFS is.

I do not know, but the way I understand, the IPFS is more like an FTP analogue, except that it is using a P2P network. In that case the solution might be some sort of a P2P-email service, where the individual emails form a forum thread. You'll need to write some custom software for that, unless You want to complicate things by trying to reuse the legacy email clients. Then the idea would be that the email would be some tar-file with some structured text, JSON, YAML, XML, with binary attachments(JPEG, GIF, MP4, WebM, etc.) and then those can be copied through whatever means, USB-sticks, plain FTP, IPFS, GNUnet, plain WWW, ZeroNet zites, etc. It would be a beautiful solution, but the reason why I haven't doen it yet, despite long planning, is that I'm not sure anybody would use it. There's the marketing side even with freely downloadable open source software. The ones, who just want to blabble around, are really not the kind of people, who are willing to lift a finger for trying out something technically novel, specially if they can just blabble on Facebook or whatever they happen to use.

tar must be preferred to compression file formats like the ZIP to avoid a DoS attack, where multiple TiB of zeros is packed to a very small file. It must be assumed that some nodes in the network will be malicious in whatever way their authors wanted them to be malicious. A P2P network must be able to handle some DoS attacks from the various government agencies. The test case that I have used is a radio-jammed battlefield: how to send letters from such environments. The various WiFi mesh networks are really NOT an option there.

> [anon05](#comment_42_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): That nofish or whoever else wouldn't be able to delete the data from all nodes of the network.

That assumes that people use multiple forks of the ZeroNet in stead of just all downloading from a single, centralized, source. The problem with the original authors is always that they might be compromised against their will. The Edward Snowden revealed that the agencies are "hunting sysadmins", but even more powerful than the sysadmins, who have access to only their own servers, are the software developers, who's creations go to the LAN's and servers of multiple sysadmins. So software developers are certainly a target for various agencies, specially, when their software becomes popular. Given that now Microsoft owns the GitHub and Microsoft has been willing to place back doors to its own software

https://web.archive.org/web/20140715035007/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/11/microsoft-nsa-collaboration-user-data

You can expect that "to comply with the law" the Microsoft will insert whatever the agencies ask to GitHub downloads. The authors upload malware free code and when somebody clones the code, the cloned code MIGHT be with malware from the agencies. So, the more forks there are "in the wild", the better, just like with genes: a biological virus or a bacteria might not be optimized to take down all of the population, only some creatures of the population. The centralized source should be seen as a blueprint for the forks to adopt components from there by thoroughly reviewing the code in the process of adopting the component source.

> [anon05](#comment_43_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): If people had to manually install an update rather than potentially destructive changes being pulled automatically I wouldn't have any issues with it.

What about initialization? If the malware is injected at the very first install, because it is known to the agency that people will be installing from location X, then my argumentation still stands. Also, if only the original authors are involved, then their thoughts are at the core of the project and they just can not spend that much time on analyzing, whether malware has been injected to their creations or not, specially if it takes place during the initial installation download and only with some of the downloads, not all of the downloads. There's the option that the initial installer hash is signed, like with Linux package collections, but do not expect ordinary end users to pay attention to those things. The Linux package installation system verifies the signatures and hashes automatically. I guess, if the original authors publish to some Linux package collection, then there might be a chance that things work out in favor of the end users, but that is NOT the case with source repository cloning.

> [anon05](#comment_44_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): Well you can't do every a 100%. There is always a hole for a sufficiently sophisticated attacker.

Right, but I want to be AWARE of the hole and know the PARAMETERS of the hole and PLAN for fixing the hole, even if I lack the resources/time for applying the countermeasures immediately :-)

> [anon05](#comment_45_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8badoP): I mean there probably are signed ZeroNet packages somewhere already, aren't there?

I'm currently too stupid to know that.

I don't know the answer to Your question, but I would start from the idea that different programming languages have different popularity among people with different occupations. That tends to influence, what is the quality of libraries for a particular task. For example, statistics related math libraries tend to be the best in programming languages that statisticians like to use, but anything that uses differential equations and numerical methods tends to be good in programming languages that physicists like to use. 3D-gaming engines are a C++ world, for historic reasons and because C++ is for speed, yet C++ is really tedious for string processing, it is only good for speed-optimized things and the actual string processing that is part of the stdlib of other programming languages is ultimately done in C or C++. May be in the case of P2P systems there might be some similar specialization, where people with different interests use different P2P-systems. The ZeroNet is certainly not for the most privacy conscious folk, those are at the Tor side. I guess the ZeroNet is more about P2P-blogs tunneled over Tor. However I would guess that if You create IoT appliance software that uses the 
https://matrix.org/
or Bitmessage in stead of using the censorednet, then You might have a really good argument for the end-users indeed, specially if You have duplicate options, like if one P2P-network gets censored, Your IoT appliance tries another one. That's not just for the privacy of the end-users, but it makes the IoT appliance literally more reliable.

> [quantumkitty](#comment_334_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): I guess there are some things the internet will never be able to replace, like buying weed from a friend.

The internet alone, may be not, but the internet and some robotics might be another story. The old-school spies used to exchange information by drop-offs, exchange of physical packages that included documents, money. That was  back in the pre-internet days. Nowadays drones might use the same idea: one drone does a drop-off, the key to the beacon is transferred over the "internet" and the package maintains radio silence till it hears the properly signed, time-dependent, signal and then returns its exact Galileo/GPS coordinates in return. Then the receiver drone can go to the randevú. Another option is that the seller drone reports its coordinates over the internet before the buyer drone even flies out and maintains radio silence all the rest of the time. Obviously the Police will be listening and locating any drone radio communication, so the exact protocol needs to be refined to something that is totally radio-silent all the way, but You get the idea. One option might even be that the seller drone is a robotic submarine, surfacing only when needed. Both robots need to be fully autonomous, that is to say, there will be no humans controlling them in real-time.

The very same problem set is relevant for information exchange, not just drug sales. Drone as a "letter dove" and in stead of drugs the "cargo" is information. May be the information is exchanged by physically handling over some USB-stick, but that's a bad idea, because the USB-stick might be a homing beacon. A better version is to transfer the information from one drone to another trough the old-school IR-optical-data-link, except that some more modern and faster version of it should be used to speed up the data transfer. Electrical contacts might also do, but then there's a risk that one drone might accidentally fry the electronics of the other drone, so something optical is better. Optical connections do not leak radio-waves, if done right, which is another aspect of operation security. Basically, the drug sales and counter-censorship-measures have a lot in common in this case.

Could You please elaborate on what do You mean by "idealists"?

> [presstodigitate](): a company, ://DeltaNova.Media , which will specialize in fixing and utilizing the Offnets, to make Alternative Media Inherently Uncensorable

I think that the best results will be achieved by focusing one's own speciality and then collaborating with others. For example, the medical projects of the Bill Gates are a huge waste of money, but for the fraction of the money he could have funded many IT-students to create start-up companies that really help the drug developing biologists to solve many serious problems. If You, the user presstodigitate, do not have a technical background Yourself, then please find Yourself a technical partner and focus on Your true strengths. The way I currently understand, Your actual current wish is:

    1) Journalists at under repressive regimes publish something.
    
    2) People under repressive regimes can read, what got published 
       even after the journalists were killed, their private keys were all ceased and 
       their servers/accounts were all ceased.

I suggest to divide that task into multiple sub-tasks and then customize the sub-tasks to the region specific circumstances. For example, it is not possible for anybody at a poor North-Korean village to read text from a computer, because computers are very expensive and catch attention due to their expense. In Africa probably the published material has to be readable from relatively small screen. I would go as far as to say that an old WAP based user interface might be the practical thing to aim for, because many Africans use old cellphones and those are not smartphones, but they do support the old WAP.  On top of the technical aspects there are the cultural aspects. May be in stead of thinking about technical solutions You should first map out the task from cultural point of view. For example, You might want to find answers to the following questions:

    Who is Your target audience?
    What is the skill set of Your target audience in terms of tech usage?
    What do You want to change by informing/brainwashing/convincing Your target audience?
    What might happen after Your target audience has read/watched/listened_to the material that You published?
    Should the published material be available years after its publication and to whom?
    Is the anonymity of the journalists important or are they kamikaze-journalists, accepting to get killed/jailed/tortured?
    If anonymity of the journalists is important, then how to remove their writing/creating style from their works?
    If anonymity of the journalists is important, then how is operational security handled?
    Should people other than the journalists be kept anonymous and safe from violence?

There are more questions than that, but only after You have figured out the answers to such questions, should You start looking for technical solutions and may be the "darknets" are not even the solution. May be as simple as drone-dropped leaflets combined with something TEMPORARILY available on the censorednet does a better job. For example, the hieroglyphs are much more concise way to write things down than the English Latin alphabet, which means that for North-Korea an ordinary leaflet can hold content wise much longer texts than the leaflet would hold, if the text were in English. May be people find it OK to use magnifying glasses, which might be plain glasses that people wear, for reading leaflets, so a whole long blog-post can be printed on a leaflet, which in turn can be passed on from person to person. I suggest You study the various old-school spy methods, document exchange methods that the Cold War era spies used. Just get Your non-technical goals right first and only after then start thinking about technical solutions and what needs to be done at the technical side. Thank You and Welcome to this forum!
